translated: This was said by the Blessed One, said by the Arahant, so I have heard:

original: “Kodhaṁ, bhikkhave, anabhijānaṁ aparijānaṁ tattha cittaṁ avirājayaṁ appajahaṁ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
analyzed: kodha bhikkhave an abhijānam a parijānam tattha cittam a virājayam a pajaham abhabbaḥ dukkha kkhayāya
translated: “Monks, without directly knowing and fully understanding anger, without making it fade away and giving it up, one is unable to make an end of suffering.

original: Kodhañca kho, bhikkhave, abhijānaṁ parijānaṁ tattha cittaṁ virājayaṁ pajahaṁ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāyā”ti.🔽Etamatthaṁ bhagavā avoca.

translated: But by directly knowing and fully understanding anger, by making it fade away and giving it up, one is able to make an end of suffering.”🔽The Blessed One said this.
And in reference to this, it was said:
Having given it up, they do not return

original: imaṁ lokaṁ kudācanan”ti.🔽Ayampi attho vutto bhagavatā, iti me sutanti.
